text: In the UK, how many professional Python developers are there, Vs the number of professional footballers?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: In the UK, how many professional Python developers are there, Vs the number of professional footballers?

text: This sounds like an interview question

elements.text: This sounds like an interview question

text: No.. it's a fatherhood question. I'm pondering the odds of success for a child aiming to be a footballer Vs a Python dev. I was sent something about a premier League player who earns minimum wage. And he must be pretty amazing. So I have a feeling that a low level Python developer probably earns more than a low level pro footballer.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: No.. it's a fatherhood question. I'm pondering the odds of success for a child aiming to be a footballer Vs a Python dev. I was sent something about a premier League player who earns minimum wage. And he must be pretty amazing. So I have a feeling that a low level Python developer probably earns more than a low level pro footballer.

text: Are those the only two options?

elements.text: Are those the only two options?

text: An apprentice dev at a big tech firm aged 19 without a degree can earn £36k/year. I know because I managed one. A 25 year old can make £60k, easily. It plateaus a bit, but your chances of making £100k a year by the age of 35 is much, much higher being a developer (and it’s not language specific), than it is being a footballer.

elements.text: An apprentice dev at a big tech firm aged 19 without a degree can earn £36k/year. I know because I managed one. A 25 year old can make £60k, easily. It plateaus a bit, but your chances of making £100k a year by the age of 35 is much, much higher being a developer (and
it’s
not language specific), than it is being a footballer.

text: Also, footballer careers end early.

elements.text: Also, footballer careers end early.

text: That said, lawyers, bankers and doctors seem to do alright as well… :joy:

elements.text: That said, lawyers, bankers and doctors seem to do alright as well

text: As to numbers: there are tens of thousands in the U.K., and there is a shortage. Bit more so than any sport.

elements.text: As to numbers: there are tens of thousands in the U.K., and there is a shortage. Bit more so than any sport.

text: What’s the best paid software tech job these days? For example would a DBA earn more than a Python dev?

elements.text: What’s
the best paid software tech job these days? For example would a DBA earn more than a Python dev?

text: Is there ever a shortage of professional sportspeople?

elements.text: Is there ever a shortage of professional sportspeople?

text: £35k without a degree as an apprentice python dev???? F*** me the world has changed a lot.

elements.text: £35k without a degree as an apprentice python dev???? F*** me the world has changed a lot.

text: Most C++ devs I know max out at 80k unless they are in finance or move to management.

elements.text: Most C++ devs I know max out at 80k unless they are in finance or move to management.

text: I guess you should also factor in injury risk as a sportsman but maybe they have specific insurance policies for that line of work?

elements.text: I guess you should also factor in injury risk as a sportsman but maybe they have specific insurance policies for that line of work?

text: My numbers are from a FAANG that aims to be 50th percentile on pay.

elements.text: My numbers are from a FAANG that aims to be 50th percentile on pay.

text: If you’re prepared to go work for Meta - which might be hard given it seems their U.K. engineering operation might be spinning down - they are known to pay 90th or 95th percentile. But you’ll hate your life.

elements.text: If
you’re
prepared to go work for Meta - which might be hard given it seems their U.K. engineering operation might be spinning down - they are known to pay 90th or 95th percentile. But
you’ll
hate your life.

text: It’s all supply/demand market economics as with anything, and this slack should understand better than most. Anything you learn at Uni - Python/Java/C++ pays less well than the languages you have to teach yourself and can find an excited CTO for - Ruby, Go, Elixir, Haskell, OCaml, for example

elements.text: It’s

all supply/demand market economics as with anything, and this slack should understand better than most. Anything you learn at Uni - Python/Java/C++ pays less well than the languages you have to teach yourself and can find an excited CTO for - Ruby, Go, Elixir, Haskell, OCaml, for example

text: I've probably cost myself a lot of potential earnings over the years. Never been interesting in working for a place that requires more than one interview stage - especially if one of those is HR specific.

elements.text: I've probably cost myself a lot of potential earnings over the years. Never been interesting in working for a place that requires more than one interview stage - especially if one of those is HR specific.

text: On the sports side of things, there is no shortage of kids prepared to play football for a living, and never will be.

elements.text: On the sports side of things, there is no shortage of kids prepared to play football for a living, and never will be.

text: I did a total of 12 hours of interviews to get into Amazon, spread over 2 batches. None of them were HR - all engineers and engineering managers asking about my experience and a few simple problem solving tasks

elements.text: I did a total of 12 hours of interviews to get into Amazon, spread over 2 batches. None of them were HR - all engineers and engineering managers asking about my experience and a few simple problem solving tasks

text: Yeah I can understand maybe in massive firms you need a few more stages of interview. I've always preferred working at a place where you get to know everyone who works there but obviously that limits your earning potential.

elements.text: Yeah I can understand maybe in massive firms you need a few more stages of interview. I've always preferred working at a place where you get to know everyone who works there but obviously that limits your earning potential.

text: the strangest language I ever came across was working at a company what developed APL interpreters. Never ever came across anyone in real life who had used APL but gurus in it earned a lot of money (apparently).

elements.text: the strangest language I ever came across was working at a company what developed APL interpreters. Never ever came across anyone in real life who had used APL but gurus in it earned a lot of money (apparently).

text: @PeterLe, best paid job I was asked to consider was for was COBOL on an S/360 in Zurich where the docs were in Swiss German, which paid €2k a day - again, supply vs demand economics. Not a fun job.

elements.text: @PeterLe, best paid job I was asked to consider was for was COBOL on an S/360 in Zurich where the docs were in Swiss German, which paid €2k a day - again, supply vs demand economics. Not a fun job.

text: APL geeks really, really, really love their APL

elements.text: APL geeks really, really, really love their APL

text: It’s like OCaml. Great language but only company that uses it really is Jane Street, so you need it if you want to work there, but learning it will lead to madness

like OCaml. Great language but only company that uses it really is Jane Street, so you need it if you want to work there, but learning it will lead to madness

text: Yes I found it a massive headf***. So many characters and symbols. Challenging to say the least.

text: 2k a day sounds a lot, but I remember what some people were being paid around this time in 1999? :open_mouth: Everyone was expecting the world to stop when we hit 00:01 1st Jan 2000 !

text:
No question that my children will be learning to program (wether they like it or not :joy:) skill for life and if you have experience you can literally walk into a job in any industry you want. 

Sports person is a huge risk in my eyes, only the top paid well / injury can put a stop to everything etc. Can’t remember his name but there was a welsh rugby player who studied at Cardiff to be a doctor whilst playing nationals, very wise

text: Jane is 100th Percentile for finance... their listed salaries for their NYC office start at 250k/USD for graduates

text: Do you think that AI stuff will help to take programming to the next level? I don't think it will put programmers out of a job. For example, it won't stop me punting on Betfair. If anything it should make programming faster, though I have yet to try it.
